title: Anointed to Go
teaser: Anointing is not to keep — it's to give. You are sent.
theme: Embracing the commissioning dimension of anointing — you are anointed to be sent

modules.greekOriginal: πορευθέντες οὖν μαθητεύσατε πάντα τὰ ἔθνη βαπτίζοντες αὐτοὺς... καὶ ἰδοὺ ἐγὼ μεθ᾽ ὑμῶν εἰμι πάσας τὰς ἡμέρας
modules.passage: Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, teaching them to observe all that I have commanded you. And behold, I am with you always, to the end of the age.

modules.meaning: to go, to journey, to proceed on one's way
modules.rootMeaning: More than simply moving from one place to another, poreuomai implies a purposeful journey — to set out with intention, to proceed toward a destination. The anointed life is a life in motion toward the world.
modules.usageNote: The Great Commission uses a participle form ('having gone' or 'as you go') — suggesting that the going is assumed. It's not 'if you go' but 'as you go, make disciples.' The anointing puts you in motion.

relatedWords.reference: apostello — to send out with a commission. Root of 'apostle.' Jesus breathed on His disciples and said 'As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you.' (John 20:21)

modules.definition: to go forth with purpose, to journey on a divine commission
modules.usage: The Great Commission doesn't ask if you'll go — it assumes it. The question isn't whether you're sent, but whether you'll walk in the sending.

modules.body:
This week we've traced the arc of anointing: chosen with purpose, empowered with the Spirit, forged in obscurity, healed in brokenness. But anointing was never meant to end with you. It was always meant to flow through you.

Jesus' final words to His disciples are not a suggestion — they're a commission. Go. Make disciples. Baptize. Teach. And the promise that makes it all possible: 'I am with you always, to the end of the age.'

The anointing you've received this week is not a private possession. It's a public assignment. Paul put it bluntly in Romans 10: 'How are they to believe in him of whom they have never heard? And how are they to hear without someone preaching? And how are they to preach unless they are sent? How beautiful are the feet of those who preach the good news!'

Your anointed feet are beautiful because they carry the gospel to people who need it.

John 20 captures the most intimate commissioning in all of Scripture. The risen Jesus appears to His frightened disciples, breathes on them, and says: 'Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you.' The breath of Christ — the same breath that spoke creation into existence — is the breath that sends you into the world.

You're not going alone. You're going as one who has been chosen, empowered, trained, and healed. Now go.
modules.keyInsight: Anointing was never meant to end with you. It was always meant to flow through you to the world around you.

modules.heading: The Anointing Flows Outward

modules.body:
A college student didn't have a dramatic testimony. She hadn't been rescued from addiction or pulled back from the edge. She just quietly showed up — for people.

When a lonely classmate sat alone at lunch, she sat down across from him. When a friend's mother passed away, she drove two hours just to sit in silence. When a freshman looked lost on the first day, she walked them to class.

She never preached a sermon. But years later, three of those people told her the same thing: 'You're the reason I believe God is real.'

She had led a quiet revival — not with words, but with anointed presence.
modules.connectionToTheme: The anointing to go doesn't always look like preaching from a stage. Sometimes it looks like sitting across from someone who needs to know they're not alone.

modules.heading: The Quiet Revival

modules.body:
There's a breathtaking detail in John 20:21-22 that changes everything about how we understand the Great Commission. Jesus doesn't just tell His disciples to go — He breathes on them.

The Greek word is 'emphysao' — and it appears only one other time in the Greek Bible: Genesis 2:7, when God breathes life into Adam. The same divine breath that animated the first human is the breath Jesus uses to commission His disciples.

This isn't a casual exhalation. It's a re-creation. Jesus is saying: 'I am making you new, and in that newness, I am sending you.' The commission and the empowerment arrive in the same breath.

And notice the framing: 'As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you.' Your sending is patterned after Jesus' own sending. He was sent to love, to heal, to proclaim, to lay down His life. Your anointing carries the same pattern.

You are not sent to perform. You are sent to love as you have been loved.
modules.historicalContext: John 20 takes place on the evening of Resurrection Sunday. The disciples are locked in a room, terrified. Jesus appears, shows His wounds, and commissions them. The sending comes not from a position of strength but from a place of fear transformed by the risen Christ.
modules.fascinatingFact: The word 'emphysao' (to breathe upon) in John 20:22 is the same word used in the Greek translation of Genesis 2:7 — God breathing life into Adam. Jesus' commissioning breath is nothing less than a new creation moment.

modules.heading: The Breath of Commission

modules.ancientTruth: Jesus breathed on His disciples — echoing God's breath in Genesis — and sent them into the world with the same anointing the Father had given Him.
modules.modernApplication: Your anointing is complete: chosen, empowered, trained in hiddenness, healed. Now the question isn't 'Am I ready?' but 'Who is in front of me right now that needs the gospel in action?'
modules.connectionPoint: The early church didn't wait for perfect circumstances. They went — into persecution, across cultures, through suffering — carrying the anointing wherever their feet landed.
modules.newTestamentEcho: Paul celebrated the beauty of going: 'How beautiful are the feet of those who preach the good news!' (Romans 10:15)

modules.prompt: Where is God calling you to go, speak, love, or show up?
additionalQuestions: Who is in front of you right now that needs the gospel in action?
What did you learn about your anointing this week?
What would it look like to say 'Here I am, send me' in your everyday life?

modules.prayerText: Here I am, Lord. Send me. This week You've shown me that I am chosen, empowered, trained, and healed — not for my own sake, but for the sake of the world You love. Give me eyes to see who is in front of me today. Give me courage to speak, to love, to show up. I don't need to be perfect — I just need to go. As the Father sent You, so You are sending me. I say yes. Amen.

modules.commitment: I will say 'yes' to one small act of obedience today and leave someone a note, voicemail, or word of encouragement.
leavingAtCross: The belief that my anointing is only for me
The fear that I don't have anything worth offering the world
The hesitation that keeps me from responding to the Spirit's prompting
receivingFromCross: The commissioning breath of Christ that sends me as the Father sent Him
The promise that He is with me always, to the end of the age
The beautiful feet of one who carries good news wherever they walk
modules.content: I will say 'yes' to one small act of obedience today and leave someone a note, voicemail, or word of encouragement.

forReflection: How does knowing that Jesus' commissioning breath echoes Genesis creation change how you understand your sending?
What does it mean that your sending is patterned after Jesus' own — 'As the Father has sent me, so I am sending you'?
Looking back over this week, how has your understanding of 'anointed' deepened or changed?
forAccountabilityPartners: Share what you learned about your anointing this week and what specific step you feel called to take
Pray the commissioning prayer together: 'Here I am. Send me.'
Commit to one act of anointed obedience this week and report back to each other

relatedScriptures.text: How beautiful are the feet of those who preach the good news!
Jesus said to them again, 'Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you.' And when he had said this, he breathed on them.
And I heard the voice of the Lord saying, 'Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?' Then I said, 'Here I am! Send me.'

forDeeperStudy.note: Read the full Resurrection appearance and commissioning — notice how Jesus moves from 'Peace' to 'Go'

modules.name: The Sent Ones
modules.title: Apostles — The Anointed and Sent
modules.description: The twelve apostles (from 'apostello' — to send) were ordinary people transformed by three years with Jesus and the outpouring of the Holy Spirit. They carried the gospel from a locked room in Jerusalem to the ends of the known world.
modules.keyQuote: As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you.
modules.lessonForUs: You don't need to be extraordinary to be sent. You just need to have been with Jesus. The anointing does the rest.
modules.heading: Apostles — The Anointed and Sent
